frames.text:
translationNotes

This page answers the question: What are the different types of translationNotes?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Help with Translating
  • Introduction to Resources

translationNotes

The translationNotes are words or phrases copied from the ULB and then explained. In English, the ULB text is in bold.

There are many different type of notes in the translationNotes. You should read all of the translationNotes for a frame or chunk of text before starting to translate it. You should also read both the ULB and the UDB and the definitions of the translationWords.

Types of translationNotes

Definitions

One type of translationNote is the definition of a word. If a word in the ULB seems special or unusual, but not important enough to be included in the translationWords, the translationNotes will have the meaning of the word. Simple definitions of words or phrases are added without quotes or sentence format. Here are examples:

  • marketplace - a large, open-air area where people would come to sell their goods
  • flute - a long, hollow musical instrument which is played by blowing air in or over one end
  • kings' palaces - a large, expensive house that a king lives in

Explanations

Simple explanations about words or phrases are in sentence format. For example:

  • washing their nets - They were cleaning their fishing nets in order to use them again to catch fish.
  • motioned - They were too far from shore to call so they made gestures, probably waving their arms.

Suggested Translations

Another type of translationNote is to give you suggestions for different ways you could translate the same meaning. There are several types of suggested translations.

Direct Replacements

Synonyms or equivalent phrases are written in double-quotes. These can replace the text in the ULB.

In this example, the words “the path” or the words “the road” can replace the words “the way” in the ULB. You can then decide if it is more natural to use a word like “path” or “road” or “way” in your language.

  • the way - “the path” or “the road”

In this example, the words “do the same thing” can replace the words “do likewise” in the ULB. You, as the translator, can decide which is more natural for your language.

  • do likewise - “do the same thing.”
Alternate Translation(s)

An alternate translation is a suggested change to the form or content of the ULB because the target language may use a different form to communicate the same meaning.

Examples include adding implicit information, changing passive voice to active, and stating rhetorical questions as statements.

The letters “AT” stand for “Alternate Translation,” so “AT:” indicates that what follows is an alternate translation that should only be used when the form or content of the ULB is confusing or is not enough to communicate the meaning in your language. Some examples are:

  • see the salvation of God - AT: “learn about how God saves people from sin.”
  • Follow me - AT: “Be my disciple” or “Come, follow me as your teacher.”

Clarifying Translation in the UDB

There may be no note if the UDB provides a good alternate translation for the ULB. However, on occasion there may text from the UDB as well as a suggested translation. In that case, there will be “(UDB)” after the text from the UDB as below:

  • implored him - “begged him” or “pleaded with him” (UDB)
  • he fell on his face - “he bowed down to the ground” (UDB) or “he knelt and touched the ground with his face”

Alternate Meaning(s)

The translationNotes will give alternate meanings when there are different ways to understand what a word or phrase means.

This kind of note will start with the words, “Possible meanings are that,” and then it will number the possible meanings with the preferred or most likely meaning first. If the meaning is given as an explanation, like the following examples, it is not in quotes.

  • You are like a young lion … like a monster in the seas - Possible meanings are that 1) he was like a lion and a monster or 2) he thought he was like a lion, but he was really only a monster.
  • like a monster in the seas - Possible meanings are that 1) he was powerful or 2) he was not doing anything important.

If the meaning is given in a way that can be used as a translation, like the following examples, it is in quotes.

  • fell down at Jesus knees - Possible meanings are 1) “bowed down at Jesus feet” or 2) “lay down on the ground at Jesus feet” or 3) “knelt down before Jesus.” Peter did not fall accidentally. He did this as a sign of humility and respect for Jesus.

Probable or Possible Meanings

Sometimes Bible scholars do not know for sure, or do not agree on, what a particular phrase or sentence in the Bible means. Some reasons for this include:

  1. There are minor differences in the ancient Bible texts.
  2. A word may have more than one meaning or use.
  3. It may not be clear what a word (such as a pronoun) refers to in a particular phrase.

See Probable or Possible Meanings for more information.

Identify Figures of Speech

The purpose of some translationNotes is to alert you to figures of speech in the ULB and to give ideas for how to translate the same meaning in a different way. Notes that identify and explain a figure of speech will use sentence form and put the meaning in quotes.

  • Make ready the way of the Lord - This phrase compares people preparing themselves for the arrival of the Lord to people who are repairing a road for someone to use it. AT: “Repent and be ready for when the Lord comes.” (See: Metaphor)
  • You offspring of poisonous snakes - Jesus uses this expression to emphasize how dangerous the Pharisees are. Poisonous snakes are dangerous and represent evil. AT: “You evil poisonous snakes!” or “You are evil like poisonous snakes.” (See: Metaphor)

If there is a translationAcademy page that explains a certain kind of figure of speech, the note will identify what kind of figure of speech it is in parentheses at the end of the note. For example, (See: Metaphor). You can then look up that kind of figure of speech in translationAcademy for more explanation.

Indirect to Direct Quote

When a translationNote is giving a direct quote as an alternative translation for an indirect quote, it will say, “This can be translated as a direct quote:” and then it will give a suggestion for how to translate it as a direct quote. For example:

  • to tell no one - This can be translated as a direct quote: “Do not tell anyone.” The implied information is “that you have been healed.” (See: Speech Quotations, Explicit and Implicit Information)

Whenever a translationNote says “See:” in parentheses at the end of the note, the words that follow are topics that you can look up in translationAcademy that will further explain the issue that the translationNote talks about.

Multiple Notes on Long Phrase

Sometimes there are notes for a phrase and also separate notes for portions of that same phrase. In that case, the larger phrase is first, and its parts come afterward. For example:

  • you say, 'Behold, he is a gluttonous man - This can be translated as an indirect quote: “you say that he is a gluttonous man” or “you accuse him of being a gluttonous man.”
  • he is a gluttonous man - “he is a greedy eater” or “he habitually eats too much food”

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Links in the translationNotes
frames.title: translationNotes

frames.text:
Links in the translationNotes

This page answers the question: Why should I use the links in the translationNotes?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Help with Translating
  • Introduction to Resources

Repeated Phrases in a Book

Sometimes a phrase is used multiple times in one book. When this happens, there will be a link in the translationNotes - green chapter and verse numbers that you can click on - that will take you back to where you have translated that phrase before. This will make it easier for you to translate this phrase by reminding you of where you have already translated it. This will make your translation faster and more consistent because you will be reminded to translate that phrase in the same way each time. If a translation that you have used before for the same phrase does not fit a new context, then you will have to think of a new way to translate it. In this case, you should make a note of it and discuss it with others on the translation team. These links will only take you back to notes in the book that you are working on.

Examples

  • be fruitful and multiply - See how you translated these commands in Genesis 12:28.
  • everything that creeps along the ground - This includes all types of small animals. See how you translated this in Genesis 1:25.
  • will be blessed in him - AT: “will be blessed because of Abraham” or “will be blessed because I have blessed Abraham.” For translating “in him,” see how you translated “through you” in Genesis12:3.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • translationNotes
  • Probable or Possible Meanings
frames.title: Links in the translationNotes

frames.text:
Translate Unknowns

This page answers the question: How do I translate words that I do not know?

How to Translate Unknowns

There are times that the source language will use words and ideas that are not familiar. If you do not know what the source word means, the Translation Notes and Important Terms pages will help you understand its meaning. Sometimes, however, a word in the source text is an object, animal, practice, or other thing that is not known to the people who speak the target language. The following information will help with translating these unknown things or concepts.

Historical facts

It is very important to remember that if the term expresses a historical fact, then that fact must be kept in a translation. For example, in Mark 11:13, Jesus cursed a fig tree. To substitute any other kind of tree would be untrue to a historical fact. To translate this, follow one of the following options:

  • Use a general descriptive phrase, such as “a fruit tree.”
  • Use a descriptive phrase with a borrowed word, such as “a tree that bears fruit called 'figs.'”
  • Use a borrowed word for the name of the tree: “a fig tree.”

For the last two choices, a footnote would be necessary to explain what “fig” means.

Another example is In John 12:14-15 where it says that Jesus rode into Jerusalem on a donkey's colt, which fulfilled a prophecy in the the Old Testament. Since it says that Jesus was sitting on a donkey's colt, which is a young donkey, the translation should not say that he sat on an ox, for example. If the word for “donkey” does not exist in the target language, a borrowed word could be used and explained in the text or in a footnote. For example, the text could say, “riding on the young of a kind of work animal called a ‘donkey.'”

This is different from the use of an animal as part of a teaching or illustration. In that case, it is not a matter of historical fact. See the example of “wolf” below.

Food and other objects

  • plow (vs hand planting)
    • See the example of translating 'plow' in Luke 9:62.
  • grapes, vineyard
  • wheat
  • bread
  • numbers, numerals

Animals

An example of the use of an animal in the Bible as an illustration is in John 10:12 where the word “wolf” is used as a way to describe a person who is harmful to God's people. There are many things to describe about a wolf but what is important in this verse is that it is a fierce and dangerous animal that frightens and harms the sheep.

If a wolf is an unknown animal in your culture, you could substitute an animal that looks similar and that has similar characteristics. For example, large wild dogs are similar to wolves. They attack and eat other animals, such as lambs. So “wolves” could be translated with a generic term like “wild dogs” or “fierce dogs” or with the name of a specific animal like a dog that your people know of, such as “coyotes” or “jackals.” You could also use a general descriptive phrase such as, “a dangerous wild animal” that focuses on the characteristics that are being highlighted in the text.

Also see the Translation Note at Luke 10:3 for other translation suggestions for wolf.

Cultural practices

There might be many differences between the biblical culture and the target language culture. Sometimes a cultural substitute can be used. But be careful not to change any historical facts (see explanation above).

The unknown biblical practice could be explained in a footnote or Bible teaching. The explanations could include a known cultural practice that has the same meaning as the one described in the Bible text. For example, in Jewish culture, grief and repentance for sin were shown by wearing a rough type of cloth (sackcloth) and putting ashes on the head. Wailing was another sign of grief. In other cultures grief may be shown in different ways. But if this practice was something that actually happened it needs to be recorded as such, with an explanation that tells what it means, perhaps using a practice from the target culture that has the same meaning.

For example, in certain cultures when men greeted other men who were family or friends, they would kiss them on one cheek or both cheeks. This can be translated as “to greet him with a kiss” or “to greet him by kissing him.” If this is not done in your culture, you could explain it with a footnote. If your readers would find it embarrassing or inappropriate to say that a man would kiss another man, you could translate it in a more general way such as, “to give him a friendly greeting.”

See the example of 'greet with a kiss' in Luke 22:47.

Translation Suggestions

Here are suggestions to keep in mind when translating a term that is not familiar in your language:

  • Use a descriptive phrase. You will most likely need to use a phrase to explain the meaning of the unknown word. It is important only to describe the part of the meaning which is being used in the particular verse being translated.
  • Substitute something similar. At times the exact word may be unknown to the people of the target language but there might be something similar that could be used in its place. Only do this if the term does not express a historical fact.
  • Use a foreign word from another language. Foreign words are words taken from a language that is not the target language. You could also use the foreign word together with a general word or descriptive phrase.
  • Use a word that is more general in meaning. An example would be “work animal” which is more general than the word “donkey.” This is acceptable because a donkey is a kind of work animal.
  • Use a word or phrase that is more specific in meaning. Sometimes there is no general word in the target language to describe the term, therefore you can give specific examples of the term being referred to. An example would be if there is no word for “lights” to refer to heavenly bodies, you could possibly say, “the sun, the moon, and the stars,” using specific words.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Translate Names
  • Copy or Borrow Words
frames.title: Translate Unknowns

frames.text:
Translate Names

This page answers the question: How do I translate names?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Translate Unknowns

Identify Something with a Proper Name:

A Proper Name (or Proper Noun) is a specific name for someone or something. In contrast, the word “mountain” is a common name–it is a general term describing a kind of landform. Mount Zion is a specific mountain in Israel; therefore, it is a Proper Name. Understanding this difference will help you as you watch the video (see link below). Within the Bible you will hear many proper names which might be unknown to the reader. It could be unclear what the name is referring to. A Proper Name could refer to a person, a country, a certain landform, a body of water, or something else. In this video you will learn how to identify what kind of thing a particular proper name is referring to.

Watch the video: for the computer see http://youtu.be/AL_rkQ8yODk , for tablet see http://youtu.be/i36kf-hyTXE .

Translation Suggestions

There are many things to keep in mind when translating a name in the Bible:

  • Proper names sometimes reveal information about the person, place, or thing it refers to.
  • Proper names of people may reveal something about the origin or history of the family.
  • Proper names of people may reveal something about a characteristic of the person.
  • Sometimes people and places have more than one name.

These are the different ways to translate names in the Bible. Discuss these with the translation team, and choose one:

  • Copy the proper name from the source language into the target language with no change. Often, this means using the name as it is spelled in the national language translation.
  • Use the name from the source language, but make adjustments to the spelling or add whatever is necessary so that it sounds like the right kind of name in the target language.
  • Pronounce the name as it is pronounced in the source language, and using the target language's spelling system, write the name in a way that people will read it with the source language's pronunciation.

If a person or place has two names, follow one of these two ways. In either case, it may be necessary to add a footnote that explains that the two names refer to the same person or place:

  • Use the name that occurs in the particular text you are translating.
  • Use one name most of the time and the other name only when the text talks about that name or the meaning of that name.

Examples from the Bible

“Having carefully investigated everything from the beginning, I also have decided to write a careful account for you, most honorable Theophilus.” -Luke 1:3

The word “honorable” describes a person. So “honorable” tells us that Theophilus is the name of a person.

“Jerusalem is where he lives; Mount Zion is his home.” -Psalms 72:2

The word “Mount” next to “Zion” lets us know that it refers to a mountain landform named “Zion” or “Mount Zion.” “Jerusalem” is the name of a city. We know it is a place because it is where someone lives, and this verse also tells us that Jerusalem is located on Mount Zion.

“Later, Jesus appeared again to the disciples beside the Sea of Galilee.” -John 21:1

The text refers to a place called the Sea of Galilee. “Sea” is our clue that the Sea of Galilee is a body of water.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Copy or Borrow Words
frames.title: Translate Names

frames.text:
Figures of Speech

This page answers the question: What are some figures of speech?

Definition

Figures of speech are ways of saying things that use words in non-literal ways. That is, the meaning of the figure of speech is not the same as the more direct meaning of the words. In order to translate the meaning, you need to be able to recognize figures of speech and know what the figure of speech means in the source language. Then you can choose either a figure of speech or a direct way to communicate that same meaning in the target language.

Types

Listed below are different types of Figures of Speech. If you would like additional information simply click the green word to be directed to a page containing definitions, examples and videos.

  • Apostrophe - In apostrophe, a speaker turns his attention from the people he is speaking to and makes an exclamation to someone who is not there with them.
  • Doublet - A doublet states the same thought in two ways. In the Bible, doublets are often used in poetry, prophecy, and sermons.
  • Euphemism - A euphemism is a mild or polite way of referring to something that is unpleasant or embarrassing. Its purpose is to avoid offending the people who hear or read it.
  • Hendiadys - In hendiadys a single idea is expressed with two words connected with “and,” when one word could be used to modify the other.
  • Hyperbole - A hyperbole is a deliberate exaggeration used to indicate the speaker’s feeling or opinion about something.
  • Idiom - An idiom is a group of words that has a meaning that is different from what one would understand from the meanings of the individual words.
  • Irony - In irony, a speaker repeats what someone has (or could have) said or thought, but he expects the listeners to understand from the context that he does not agree with it.
  • Litotes - Litotes is an emphatic statement made by saying that the opposite idea is not true.
  • Merism - This is a figure of speech that refers to both extremes and everything in between.
  • Metaphor - A metaphor is a figure of speech in which words for one thing or action are applied to something else in order to imply that there is something that the two things have in common. Like simile, this involves a comparison, but the words ‘like’ and ‘as’ are not used to show it.
  • Metonymy - Metonymy is a figure of speech in which a thing or idea is called not by its own name, but by the name of something closely associated with it. A metonym is a word or phrase used as a substitute for something it is associated with.
  • Parallelism - Parallelism is the expression of one idea in two or more different ways. Parallelism is most commonly found in the book of Psalms and Proverbs but is found throughout the whole of the Hebrew Bible.
  • Personification - Personification is a kind of simile or metaphor, in which an idea or something that is not human is referred to as if it were a person and could do the things people do or have the attributes people have.
  • Rhetorical Question - A rhetorical question is a question that is used for something other than getting information. Often it indicates the speaker’s attitude toward the topic or the listener. Often it is used for rebuking or scolding, but some languages have other purposes as well.
  • Simile - In a simile something is compared to something else of a different kind in order to focus on a particular trait that they have in common. The fact that there is a comparison is stated clearly with ‘like’ or ‘as’. The thing that is being talked about is the “topic.” The thing it is compared to is the “image.” The trait that they have in common is the “point of similarity.”
  • Synecdoche - Synecdoche is a figure of speech in which 1) the name of a part of something is used to refer to the whole thing, or 2) the name of a whole thing is used to refer to just one part of it.

Idiom

This page answers the question: What is an idiom?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Figures of Speech

Definition

An idiom is a group of words that has a meaning that is different from what one would understand from the meanings of the individual words.

Translation Suggestions

  • Use the original idiom if it would be clearly understood in your language.
  • Use a different idiom that people use in your own language that has the same meaning.
  • Translate the meaning plainly without using an idiom.

Examples from the Bible

“But I have a baptism to be baptized with, and how distressed I am until it is accomplished!” -Luke 12:50 (WEB)

A “baptism to be baptized with” is an idiom for suffering. Jesus meant that he would soon suffer greatly.

“Moses came near to the camp, and saw the calf and the dancing, and Moses' nose burned,” -Exo 32:19

“His nose burned” is a Hebrew idiom that means, “He became angry.”

“You are all sons of light, and sons of the day.” -1 Thes 5:5a (WEB)

The phrase “sons of” is a Hebrew idiom used to refer to people who have certain characteristics. Jews used this idiom even when speaking Greek. “Sons of light” refers to people who live according to the truth.

Examples from English

“He saw the light.”

means “He finally understood.”

“It cost an arm and a leg.”

means “It was very expensive.”

“Let's play it by ear.”

means “Let's improvise” or “Let's see what happens and make decisions based on that.”

“She had butterflies in her stomach.”

means “She was nervous.”

Irony

This page answers the question: What is irony?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Figures of Speech

Definition

Irony is using words that appear to say the opposite of what you mean. Irony is typically used to be humorous or to place emphasis on how different something is from what it should be, or how far someone's belief is from the truth. Irony makes these points more powerfully than direct statements do. In irony, sometimes a speaker repeats what someone has (or could have) said or thought, but he expects the listeners to understand from the context that he does not agree with it.

Translation Suggestions

  • If the irony would be understood correctly, translate it as is.
  • If the irony would not be understood correctly, you could indicate that the thoughts are not truly those of the speaker but of someone else. For example, In Mark 7:9, Jesus says to the Pharisees, “Rightly you set aside the commandment of God in order to set up your own tradition.” Jesus is putting into words what the Pharisees actually do, even though they would never admit that they do this. Everyone who hears this, including Jesus, knows that it is wrong to set aside a commandment of God. So Jesus is rebuking the Pharisees in a powerful way by using words that seem to commend them for doing wrong. If the irony would not be understood, this could be translated as “You think you have done well in following your traditions. But as you do that, you have rejected God's commandments.”

Examples from the Bible

Having blindfolded him, they struck him on the face and asked him, “Prophesy! Who is the one who struck you?” -Luke 22:64b (WEB)

The soldiers were hitting Jesus and they told him to prophecy and say who hit him. This was irony. They were implying that if he were a prophet, he should be able to tell who hit him, but they did not believe that he was a real prophet. They told him to prophecy because they were mocking him and wanted to prove that he was not really a prophet.

If the irony would not be understood here, the soldier's words could be translated more directly as, “You are not a prophet - you cannot even tell us who struck you.”

When Jesus heard it, he said to them, “Those who are healthy have no need for a physician, but those who are sick. I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.” -Mark 2:17a (WEB)

When Jesus spoke here of righteous people, that was irony. Jesus knew that there are no righteous people. But some people thought that they really were righteous, and they didn't think that Jesus should allow sinners to follow him. But Jesus invited sinners to go to him and turn from their sins. He was not inviting people who think they are righteous and think that they do not need to turn from their sins. Only people who know that they are sinners would repent of their sins.

If the irony would not be understood here, part of Mark 2:17 could be translated as “I have not come to call those who think they are righteous to repentance, but those who know they are sinners.”

Examples from English

“The used-car salesman told me that this car was a great bargain at only $1000, so I bought it. But now I find out that the radiator doesn't work, and it will cost me $4000 to get it repaired. Great bargain. Yeah, right.”

In this example, the speaker uses irony to express that the reality of the car was totally different than what the car salesman said, so he repeats the car salesman's words, but now mocking them as false.

“Thanks for holding the door open for me.”

This would be an ironic statement made to someone who did not hold the door open for the speaker. It expresses that the other person should have been kind enough to hold it open, and that the speaker is annoyed with that person for not doing that. The expression of thanks for something that both the hearer and the speaker know that the hearer did not do has become, through irony, a rebuke for not doing it.

frames.text:
Metaphor

This page answers the question: What is a metaphor?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Figures of Speech

Definition

A metaphor is a figure of speech that creates a 'word picture' by relating one thing (the topic of the metaphor) to an unrelated object. Metaphors imply (or state directly) that the two things have something in common. Like simile, this involves a comparison, but the words ‘like’ and ‘as’ are not used to show it. (See Simile.). A metaphor transfers an image from one familiar object to another object that is less easily understood.

For example, “Life is a journey,” is a metaphor that helps convey a concept about life - that it is like a journey in some way - perhaps because in both you are always moving along and progressing, not staying in the same place. In this example, “life” is the topic, “a journey” is the image that is being applied to the topic, and the concept of movement or progression is the point of similarity. Every metaphor has a topic, an image, and a point of similarity. But as with this example, usually the point of similarity is not stated. Often the author expects the reader or hearer to think about the comparison and see the point of similarity for themselves.

Purposes of Metaphor

  • One purpose of metaphor is to teach about something that is unknown by indicating that it is similar to something that is already known.
  • Another purpose of metaphor is to emphasize that something has a particular trait or to indicate that it has that particular trait in an extreme way.
  • Another purpose of metaphor is to lead people to react emotionally to one thing as they would to another.

Translation Suggestions

  • If the image in the original is unknown to your people, use an image from your own culture. Be sure that it is an image that could have been possible in Bible times. We don't want to have comparisons to things that had not been invented when the books of the Bible were first written.
  • Or if the image in the original is unknown to your people, simply state the point of similarity without using an image.
  • If it would be unclear to your readers how the topic is like the image, you can state the point of similarity clearly. However, do not do this if it was also not clear to the original audience.
  • If the topic is not stated clearly in the original and it would be unclear to your readers what the topic is, state the topic clearly. However, do not do this if the topic was not clear to the original audience. For example, in Matthew 16:6, Jesus told his disciples “Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees.” His disciples thought he was talking about bread, but Jesus was warning them about the teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees. That was the topic, but it was unstated, and the disciples did not understand it at first. If the metaphor were fully stated, it would be, “The teaching of the Pharisees is like yeast.” the point of similarity is that they both spread throughout whatever they touch and change it.
  • If the target audience would not understand the metaphor, then change the metaphor to a simile by adding “like” or “as”.

Examples from the Bible

Jesus said to them. “I am the bread of life. He who comes to me will not be hungry, and he who trusts in me will never be thirsty.“ John 6:35

Jesus compared himself to bread, a food that people ate all the time then. Just as people need to eat food in order to have physical life, people need to trust in Jesus in order to have spiritual life.

… the rising sun will come from heaven to help us, to shine on those who sit in darkness and the shadow of death. Luke 1:78b-79a

This verse has several related metaphors. The Savior is compared to the rising sun, teaching spiritual truth is compared to the sun shining, lacking spiritual truth is compared to sitting in darkness, and the fear of death is compared to a shadow. This means that just as the rising sun shines on those who have been living in darkness, the Savior will come and bring spiritual truth to those who lack spiritual truth and are afraid of death.

Examples from English

“He was a walking dictionary.”

Because he knows the meanings of so many words, he is compared to a dictionary. Dictionaries contain the meanings of many words.

“Her heart broke when her baby died.”

Her heart, or emotions, is compared to a physical thing that can break.

To learn more about metaphor, watch the video on computer (see http://youtu.be/ofxhv443COM ) or on tablet/phone( see http://youtu.be/2W0qm9xIPeU ).

Rhetorical Question

This page answers the question: What is a rhetorical question?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Figures of Speech

Definition

A rhetorical question is a question that is used for something other than getting information. An answer is not expected for rhetorical questions. A rhetorical question may be used to express deep emotion or to encourage the reader to think deeply on a topic. At times, rhetorical questions are used for sarcasm, rebuking or scolding. Some languages have other purposes as well.

Watch the video on the “Kinds of Questions” for computer (see http://youtu.be/ePSJS2RVoV4 ) or the tablet/phone (see http://youtu.be/7c-7LOqLBp4 ) to learn the difference between real and rhetorical questions.

Translation Suggestions

  • Determine the purpose of the rhetorical question.
  • If your language would use a rhetorical question for that purpose, then use it.
  • Languages may have different forms of rhetorical questions for different purposes. For example, if a parent wants to scold or rebuke his child for writing on the walls, some languages could do it with different forms of rhetorical questions, such as: “Why are you writing on the wall?” or “Who told you to write on the wall?” or “Is that your wall that you are writing on?” Other languages would use a statement, such as: “I told you not to write on the walls,” or a command, such as: “Do not write on the walls!”
  • If, after determining the purpose of the rhetorical question, your decide that your language would use a statement or a command for that purpose, then use a statement or command instead of a rhetorical question. For example, in Mark 13:2, Jesus says to one of his disciples, “Do you see these great buildings?” (ULB). Jesus knows that the disciple sees them, but he uses a rhetorical question to draw attention to them. If your language would not use a rhetorical question to draw people's attention to something, then use whatever form is natural, such as a command, “Look at these great buildings,” or a statement, “These buildings are very great.”

Examples from the Bible

Zechariah said to the angel, “How will I know this will happen? For I am an old man, and my wife also is very old.” -Luke 1:18 (ULB)

When Zechariah asked this rhetorical question, he was indicating that he could not believe that what the angel said was true.

Everyone who heard about this kept thinking about what had happened and said, “So then, what will this child become?” For they realized that the hand of the Lord was with him. -Luke 1:66 (ULB)

The people were not expecting anyone to answer their question. They were simply expressing that they wondered about it because they were impressed by the surprising things they had heard about his birth.

Examples from English

“Could you do this for me?”

Someone could say this if they want to politely tell someone to do something.

“What possessed you to think of doing that?”

A mother might scold her child by saying this.

Simile

This page answers the question: What is a simile?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Figures of Speech

Definition

In a simile something is compared to something else of a different kind in order to focus on a particular trait that they have in common. Unlike with metaphor, with simile the fact that there is a comparison is stated clearly with ‘like’ or ‘as.’

Purposes of Simile

  • One purpose of simile is to teach about something that is unknown by indicating that it is similar to something that is already known.
  • Another purpose is to emphasize that something has a particular trait or to indicate that it has that particular trait in an extreme way.
  • Similes also help you to form a picture in your mind of something; to experience what you are reading about more fully.

Translation Suggestions

  • If the image in the original is unknown to your people, use one from your own culture. Be sure that it is one that could have been used in the cultures of the Bible. We don't want to have comparisons to things that had not been invented when the books of the Bible were first written.
  • Or if the image in the original is unknown to your people, simply state the point of similarity without using an image.
  • If it would be unclear to your readers how the topic is like the image, you can state the point of similarity explicitly. However, do not do this if it was not clear to the original audience.

Examples from the Bible

How often I wanted to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you refused! -Luke 13:34b

In this simile, Jesus compared the protection he wanted to give the people of Jerusalem to the kind of protection a hen gives to her chicks when they are in danger. It's not that he would literally gather the people underneath him, but he would protect them and they would trust him.

For as the lightning flashes in one part of the sky and shines to the other part of the sky, so will it be when the Son of Man comes in his day. -Luke 17:24

Jesus did not say how his coming back to earth would be like when lightning flashes. But we can understand from the rest of the text that just as lighting flashes suddenly and everyone can see it, he will come suddenly and everyone will be able to see him. No one will have to be told about it.

Examples from English

“He is as crooked as a dog's hind leg.”

Someone might say this about a businessman who is dishonest. English speakers associate truth with being straight and dishonesty with crookedness.

“She was as cool as a cucumber.”

Someone might say this about a person who doesn't get emotional in a very stressful situation. English speakers associate emotion with heat and lack of emotion with coolness.

To learn more about simile, watch the video on computer (see http://youtu.be/ylwbrp-vVgI ) or tablet/phone (see http://youtu.be/LQdDDn-d_ak ).

Word Order

This page answers the question: Is word order important?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Important Information about English Grammar

Parts of a Sentence

A basic sentence has three important parts: subject, object, and verb. Both subjects and objects are usually nouns (i.e. a person, place, thing, or idea). Verbs show action or a “state of being.”

  • The subject of a sentence is what the sentence is about.
  • The subject (which will be a noun: a person, place, thing, or idea) is usually the main “actor” in a sentence.
  • The “actor” or subject usually does some action or is being described in some way.

When the subject is identified, determine what it is doing (or what is happening to it).

  • A subject may be active: it can perform or do something such as “sing,” or “work,” or “teach.”
  • A subject can be in a state such as “happy,” “sad,” or “mad.”
  • Or a subject may have something done to it.
    • For example, “The ball was thrown.” (The ball is the subject.)

The object of a sentence is a recipient (that is NOT the subject). The object will also be a person, place, thing, or idea.

In a simple sentence the subject usually does something to or towards an object. Consider the sentence:

“The boy kicked the ball.”

The boy is the subject; the recipient or object is the ball. The subject (boy) does some action (kicked) to the object (ball).The VERB tells what the action is that the subject is doing (or being).

Often it is easy to find the verb, because one looks for the action occurring in the sentence.

Translation Suggestions

All languages have a preferred word order. Translate sentences so that they are accurate and have a smooth flow.

Word order or patterns can vary if the sentence:

  • is a question
  • has descriptive words
  • has a place in it
  • has time in it
  • has a condition in it, such as the word “if”
  • is a poem

Sometimes the word order will also vary if there is a special type of emphasis. For example, perhaps in your language there is a special way to ask a rhetorical question or give a command. Knowing the preferred word order of the source text and how it is different than the target language can help a translator in translating from that language into the target language. This is especially true if your language does not have the same pattern. If the two languages have a different preferred word order for communicating the same things, then you will need to rephrase the sentence into the order that is preferred in the target language in order to make your translation sound natural. The translator’s goal is always to use natural language to make the meaning clear.

Language Examples

Now we will look at the importance of word order.

English

In English, “The boy kicked the ball”. “The boy” is the subject, “kicked” is the verb, and “the ball” is the object.

This is the basic word order that English uses to communicate statements. First we say the subject, then the verb, and then the object. We can represent the Subject, Verb and Object with the letters “S”, “V” and “O”. So, we can call English an SVO Language.

Japanese, Chines, Dutch and Turkish

In the Japanese, Chinese, Dutch, and Turkish languages usually the subject is first, and then the object comes next, followed by the verb.

So the basic word order for a simple sentence for these languages is: Subject – Object – Verb, or SOV.

Hebrew and Arabic

In the Hebrew and Arabic languages, the order for sentences is normally Verb – Subject – Object, or VSO.

In order to translate from one of these languages into another, it is very important to change the order of the sentence into the preferred order for the target language. Only by doing this will the translation be natural and clear.

Also view the video for computer (see http://youtu.be/PzMpNyCNlLQ ) or portable device (see http://youtu.be/jxeGp2-TuZg ).

Forms of You

This page answers the question: What are the different forms of you?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • English Parts of Speech

Singular / Dual / Plural

Some languages have more than one word for ‘you’ depending on how many people are being spoken to. If they are speaking to one person, they use the ‘singular’ form of “you.” If they are speaking to more than one person, they use the “plural” form of “you.” Some languages have a “dual” form for speaking to two people and some have other forms for speaking to three or four people.

Watch the video for Singular / Dual / Plural for computer (see http://youtu.be/cPtjzJ2Advk ) or tablet/phone (see http://youtu.be/AVITfDEk8nc ).

For more information regarding Singular forms of you see Forms of 'You' - Singular.

For more information regarding Dual / Plural forms of you Forms of 'You' - Dual/Plural.

Formal / Informal

Some languages also have different forms of “you” to indicate respect or social distance. They use the formal form of “you” when addressing someone who is an elder or respected or in authority. They use the informal “you” when talking with a peer or someone with less authority. Because the Bible was written in languages that do not have this difference, the translator will need to decide when it is best to use formal or informal forms of the language.

Watch the video on Formal / Informal for computer (see http://youtu.be/MwbYo9dZUDc ) or the tablet/phone (see http://youtu.be/XfgVYqbugYE ).

For more information regarding Formal / Informal forms of you, see Forms of 'You' - Formal and Informal.

frames.text:
Forms of 'You' - Dual/Plural

This page answers the question: How do I know if the word 'you' is dual or plural?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • English Parts of Speech

Forms of "You" in the Bible

The Bible was first written in the Hebrew and Greek languages. These languages both have a singular form of you and a plural form of you. Therefore we know when each “you” in the Bible should be 'singular' (see Forms of 'You' - Singular) or plural. But even when reading the Bible in a language that does not have distinct singular and plural forms of “you,” the context will often make it clear whether the word “you” is intended to refer to one person, to two people, or to more than two people. If the target language has a dual form of “you” that is used for speaking to only two people, the translator will need to decide from the context when it is appropriate to use this form.

Some languages, like English, have only one word for ‘you’ regardless of how many people are being spoken to. English speakers can refer to one person as ‘you’ or to many people as ‘you.’ Often the context will make it clear as to whether the word ‘you’ refers to one person or more than one. Looking at the other pronouns in the sentence will help you distinguish the number of people who are being spoken to.

Some languages have more than one word for ‘you’ depending on how many people are being spoken to. If they are speaking to one person, they use the ‘singular’ form of ‘you’. If they are speaking to more than one person, they use the ‘plural’ (see Forms of 'You' - Dual/Plural) form of ‘you.’ Some languages have a ‘dual’ (see Forms of 'You' - Dual/Plural) form for speaking to two people and some have other forms for speaking to three or four people.

Translation Suggestions

Note that for many languages, the decision about what form of the pronoun to use will also affect the form of the verb associated with it, even in cases where the word “you” is not expressed (for example when a command is given).

Examples from the Bible

And James and John, the sons of Zebedee, came up to him and said to him, “Teacher, we want you to do for us whatever we ask of you.” And [Jesus] said to them, “What do you want me to do for you?” -Mark 10:35-36

Jesus is asking the two, James and John, what they want him to do for them. If the target language has a dual form of “you,” it would be appropriate to use it here. If the target language does not have a dual form, then the plural form would be appropriate.

…Jesus sent two of his disciples, saying to them, “Go to the village ahead of you, and just as you enter it, you will find a colt tied there, which no one has ever ridden. Untie it and bring it here. -Mark 11:1-2

The context makes it clear that Jesus is addressing two persons, so the dual form of “you” would be used here in languages that make that distinction. Here the verbs “go” and “untie” would also need the dual form.

In instructional text, the “you” is often plural since it is addressing a wide audience. Here is an example:

Since you call on a Father who judges each man’s work impartially, live your lives as strangers here in reverent fear. -1 Peter 1:17

frames.text:
Forms of 'You' - Singular

This page answers the question: How do I know if the word 'you' is singular?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • English Parts of Speech

Forms of "You" in the Bible

The Bible was first written in the Hebrew and Greek languages. These languages both have a singular form of you and a plural form of you. Therefore we know when each “you” in the Bible should be 'singular' (see Forms of 'You' - Singular) or plural. But even when reading the Bible in a language that does not have distinct singular and plural forms of “you,” the context will often make it clear whether the word “you” is intended to refer to one person, to two people, or to more than two people. If the target language has a dual form of “you” that is used for speaking to only two people, the translator will need to decide from the context when it is appropriate to use this form.

Some languages, like English, have only one word for ‘you’ regardless of how many people are being spoken to. English speakers can refer to one person as ‘you’ or to many people as ‘you.’ Often the context will make it clear as to whether the word ‘you’ refers to one person or more than one. Looking at the other pronouns in the sentence will help you distinguish the number of people who are being spoken to.

Some languages have more than one word for ‘you’ depending on how many people are being spoken to. If they are speaking to one person, they use the ‘singular’ form of ‘you’. If they are speaking to more than one person, they use the ‘plural’ (see Forms of 'You' - Dual/Plural) form of ‘you.’ Some languages have a ‘dual’ (see Forms of 'You' - Dual/Plural) form for speaking to two people and some have other forms for speaking to three or four people.

Translation Suggestions

Note that for many languages, the decision about what form of the pronoun to use will also affect the form of the verb associated with it, even in cases where the word “you” is not expressed (for example when a command is given).

Examples from the Bible

He said, “I have observed all these things from my youth up.” When Jesus heard this, he said to him, “You still lack one thing. Sell everything you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.” -Luke 18:21, 22

Note that even though English does not have singular and plural forms of ‘you’, the context indicates that this word ‘you’ here only refers to one person. The man had just told Jesus “I have observed these things” and Jesus responded with “you”, referring only to that one man.

Then the angel said to him, “Put on your clothes and sandals.” And Peter did so. “Wrap your cloak around you and follow me,” the angel told him. -Acts 12:8

The context makes it clear that the angel is addressing one person, so the singular form of “you” would be used here in languages that make that distinction. The verbs “put on“ and “wrap” would also need the singular form.

To Titus, my true son in our common faith…The reason I left you in Crete was that you might straighten out what was left unfinished and appoint elders in every town, as I directed you….You must teach what is in accord with sound doctrine.” -Titus 1:2,5; 2:1

Sometimes instruction is addressed to only one person, so the singular form of “you“ would be used. The context will make that clear. This often happens in a letter.

Also watch the video for computer (see http://youtu.be/cPtjzJ2Advk ) or tablet/phone (see http://youtu.be/AVITfDEk8nc ).

frames.text:
Explicit and Implicit

This page answers the question: What do the words explicit and implicit mean?

Definition

There are two different forms of communication found in both written and spoken messages. One is called explicit and the other is called implicit. When a speaker, or writer, has a message to give, he has a particular audience in mind as he gives the message. This affects the form of his message and his decision on what information to include or leave out.

  • Information that the speaker states clearly is called explicit information. This is the information that the speaker or writer has decided to include in what he says.
  • Information that the speaker does not state clearly is called implicit information. This is the information that the speaker or writer expects his audience to already know, and so he knows that he does not need to include that information in what he writes.

When a writer writes, he has in mind a certain audience who will read what he writes. The writer has a good idea of what this audience does and does not know about what he is writing about, and so the writer chooses to include the important information that he knows his audience does not know. He chooses to not include the information that his audience already knows.

Translation Suggestions

Although implicit information is not stated in words but is only implied, it is information that the hearer or reader needs to know if he is to understand the meaning of the message. The speaker or writer has succeeded in communicating his message only if the hearer or reader correctly understands what was clearly stated as well as what was implied.

When we translate the Bible, we are making it available to a new audience. This new audience will know some things about what is in the Bible, but often they will not know some of the implicit information that the original writer left out because his original audience already knew it. The new target audience, then, will need to know some of that implicit information in order to understand some parts of the text. So in order for the Bible to communicate its message successfully, the translator needs to include some of the information that the original writer left as implicit for the original audience. If this information can be included in just a few words, then the translator may decide to include this information in the text of the translation. But if it will take more than a few words, it is best to include this information in a footnote. The translator will need to think about his target audience and decide when to include some of this implicit information. Checking the translation with the community is a good way for the translator to find out where he needs to include some implicit information so that they can understand the translation.

frames.text:
Making Implicit Information Explicit

This page answers the question: How do I make implicit information explicit?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Explicit and Implicit

Explanation

When a writer writes a message, he includes the information that his audience needs to know, and leaves out the information that he knows that they already know. When we translate a message, such as the Bible, for a new audience, they may not know some of that information that the original writer did not say. That is the implicit information. Because the author is counting on the audience knowing this implicit information, this information is also part of the message, even though it is not stated. So in the places where the target audience needs to know the implicit information in order to understand the text, and they do not know it, you must put it in the translation, either in the text or in a footnote.

But translators need to be particularly sensitive when thinking about adding such information to the translation that is not stated explicitly in the source text because:

  • Sometimes there will be things that are intentionally unclear in the text. In those cases, the translator should try to keep it unclear also in the translation, if it is possible to keep it unclear in the same way.
  • It is not necessary to include all implicit information for the target audience to understand the text. There is a lot of information that the original audience knew about the things that are in the Bible. Only include the information that the target audience needs to know so that the message is clear, nothing more.

The translator's goal should be to make sure that the reader understands the original meaning of the message. The translation should always have the same meaning as the source text had for its original audience, not more meaning, not less meaning, and not different meaning.

Implicit information may be made explicit in order to make the translation clear if:

  • Only the implicit information that the original audience would have known is made explicit,
  • the added information is necessary so that the target audience will understand the main point of the message,
  • The translation would communicate no meaning or a wrong meaning without the added information,
  • No new information is added that is not part of the original message (do not add something just because you read it in a commentary),
  • the added information does not change the meaning, making it no longer true or accurate,
  • the added information is suitable to the original situation in which the message was given.

As always, you need to ask yourself if your translation is communicating accurately and clearly what the original message was saying.

Examples from the Bible

She ate all that she wanted and had some left over. -Ruth 2:14

Some languages may need to add an object where English (or whatever source language is being used) doesn't have one. Here, the implied object is “roasted grain” or simply “food.” If the target language requires an object for these verbs, you could translate, She ate all the roasted grain that she wanted and had some food left over.

So Yahweh came down to see the city and the tower which the descendants of Adam had built. -Genesis 11:5

The phrase “came down” refers to where he came from. The place he came from was understood by the original readers. But if this sentence is unclear for the target audience, you may name the place to make the information explicit as in: So Yahweh came down from heaven to see the city and the tower which the descendants of Adam had built.

These latter five kings joined together in the valley of Siddim (also called the Salt Sea). -Genesis 14:3

The information that the armies of the five kings were with these five kings was understood by the original readers. But if this information is not understood by the target audience, the information that their armies were with them can be made explicit: “These latter five kings and their armies joined together….”

To Enoch was born Irad. Irad became the father of Mehujael. -Genesis 4:18

It is stated explicitly that Enoch had a child named Irad and that Irad had a child named Mehujael. The implied information is that Irad grew up to be a man and married a woman and through her, had a son. If the verse is confusing without this information for the target audience, you may add as much information as is necessary, such as, “Enoch grew up and married and became the father of a son whom he named Irad. When Irad grew up he became the father of a son whom he named Mehujael.”

Examples from English

  • David asks Susan: “Where is Joe?” David’s question is explicit because it is clearly stated and easily understood by Susan.
  • Susan answers, “At work.” Susan’s response leaves out who she is talking about - this information is implicit. But David understands that information and that her message is, in fact, “Joe is at work.”

Hypothetical Situations

This page answers the question: What are hypothetical situations?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Figures of Speech

Definition

Something that is hypothetical is 'assumed' or 'supposed.' A hypothetical situation is a possible scenario from any point in time: past, present or future. A hypothetical situation in the past did not happen, but could have happened under different circumstances. A hypothetical situation in the present or future may or may not actually happen - the speaker presents it as hypothetical because he does not know or it depends on the actions of others. It could possibly happen or it may never happen. A hypothetical situation might mean asking a “what if” question. It might be a “suppose” or “if only” statement. Hypothetical situations are good teaching tools. Jesus often used them in his teaching.

Translation Suggestions

  • How would your language express a situation that could never happen?
  • How would you communicate a “suppose” scenario that could happen right now?
  • How would your language express a situation that may or may not happen in the future?
  • Does your language have a special way of indicating a hypothetical situation in the past?
  • How does your language express an “if only” or “I wish” scenario which also implies some emotion?

It is important in translation to be able to recognize a hypothetical situation in the text and use appropriate words or phrases. You may need to show the timing of the hypothetical situation (e.g. past, present or future). You may need to clarify that the scenario is only a possibility: that it might be true or not likely to be true; that it could possibly happen or would never happen. Hypothetical situations may or may not imply emotions or reasons. Some hypothetical statements may use expressions such as “what if”, “suppose” or “if only” to help the reader understand the type of hypothetical situation. Perhaps your language uses special wording or specific language structures to communicate each of these things.

Examples from the Bible

1. Consider a hypothetical situation that would never happen:

In Luke chapter 18 verse 25 Jesus was teaching his disciples about how being rich can make it hard to enter God’s kingdom. To emphasize this, he said that it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to submit to God’s rule in their life.

The hypothetical part of this is that a large camel could never squeeze through the eye of a very small sewing needle! Jesus used this hypothetical scenario to emphasize his teaching point.

2. Consider a “suppose” scenario that could possibly happen.

In Matthew chapter 12 verse 11, Jesus was pointing out to the religious leaders that they were not being honest when they judged people for working on the Sabbath day. He told them, “Suppose one of you has a sheep and it falls into a deep hole on the Sabbath day. Certainly, you would work to pull it out of the hole!”

Jesus wasn’t talking about a specific person who did this. Rather, he was talking about a possible situation which could and often did happen. He used the hypothetical story to help listeners understand his own work (God's work).

3. The following is an example of a hypothetical scenario in the past:

In Matthew 11:21, Jesus said that if the people living in the ancient cities of Tyre and Sidon had been able to see the miracles that he – Jesus – performed, they would have repented long ago.

This is a hypothetical situation that we know did not happen. Jesus was making the spiritual teaching point of “what if” these people had seen the miracles? If they had seen the miracles, then, they would have repented.

4. Often a hypothetical situation in the past expresses an emotion, such as regret. For example, consider Exodus 16:3:

“If only we had died by the hand of Yahweh in the land of Egypt….”

Here the Israelites are afraid that they will have to suffer and die of hunger in the wilderness, and so they are wishing that they had stayed in Egypt and died there with full stomachs.

Order of Events

This page answers the question: Why are the events not listed in the order they happened, and how do I translate them?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Writing Styles

In the Bible, events are not always told in the order in which they occurred. Sometimes the author wanted to discuss something that happened at an earlier time than the event that he just wrote about. This can be confusing to the reader.

Description

In the Bible, events are not always told in the order in which they occurred. Sometimes the author wanted to discuss something that happened at an earlier time than the event that he just talked about. This can be confusing to the reader.

Reason this is a translation issue: Readers might think that the events happened in the order that they are told. It is important to help them understand the correct order of events.

Examples from the Bible

But then Herod … had John locked up in prison. Now it came about, while all the people were being baptized by John, that Jesus also was baptized. (Luke 3:20-21)

This can sound like John baptized Jesus in prison.

Just as Joshua had said to the people, the seven priests carried the seven trumpets of rams horns before Yahweh, as they advanced, they gave a blast on the trumpets… But Joshua commanded the people, saying, “Do not shout. No sound must leave your mouths until the day I tell you to shout. Only then must you shout.” (Joshua 6:8-10)

This sounds like Joshua gave the order not to shout after the army had already started their march.

Who is worthy to open the scroll and break its seals? (Revelation 5:2)
The seals that lock the scroll must be broken before the scroll can be unrolled.

Translation Strategies

  1. If your language uses phrases, time words or verb tenses to show that an event happened before the one just mentioned, consider using one of them. (See: Verbs)
  2. If your language prefers to tell events in the order that they occurred, consider reordering the events so they they are in that order. This may require putting two or more verses together (like 5-6). (See: Verse Bridges)

Examples of Translation Strategies Applied

1. If your language uses phrases, time words or tenses to show that an event happened before the one just mentioned, consider using one of them.

  • 20 But then Herod … had John locked up in prison. 21 Now it came about, while all the people were being baptized by John, that Jesus also was baptized. (Luke 3:20-21)
    • 20 But then Herod … had John locked up in prison. 21 Before John was put in prison, while all the people were being baptized by John, Jesus also was baptized.
  • 8 Just as Joshua had said to the people, the seven priests carried the seven trumpets of rams horns before Yahweh, as they advanced, they gave a blast on the trumpets…10 But Joshua commanded the people, saying, “Do not shout. No sound must leave your mouths until the day I tell you to shout. Only then must you shout.” (Joshua 6:8-10)
    • 8 Just as Joshua had said to the people, the seven priests carried the seven trumpets of rams horns before Yahweh, as they advanced, they gave a blast on the trumpets…10 But Joshua had commanded the people, saying, “Do not shout. No sound must leave your mouths until the day I tell you to shout. Only then must you shout.”
  • Who is worthy to open the scroll and break its seals? (Revelation 5:2)
    • “Who is worthy to open the scroll after breaking its seals?”

2. If your language prefers to tell events in the order that they occur, consider reordering the events. This may require putting two or more verses together (like 5-6).

  • 8 Just as Joshua had said to the people, the seven priests carried the seven trumpets of rams horns before Yahweh, as they advanced, they gave a blast on the trumpets…10 But Joshua commanded the people, saying, “Do not shout. No sound must leave your mouths until the day I tell you to shout. Only then must you shout.” (Joshua 6:8-10)
    • 8-10 Joshua commanded the people, saying, “Do not shout. No sound must leave your mouths until the day I tell you to shout. Only then must you shout.” Then just as Joshua had said to the people, the seven priests carried the seven trumpets of rams horns before Yahweh, as they advanced, they gave a blast on the trumpets…
  • Who is worthy to open the scroll and break its seals? (Revelation 5:2)
    • Who is worthy to break the seals and open the scroll?

frames.text:
Parables

This page answers the question: What is a parable?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • Figures of Speech

Explanation

The kind of communication that we call “parable” includes narrative stories, metaphors, similes, proverbs, and even riddles. The intent of a parable is to convey meaning through a story or word picture. A parable is not an actual account of an event; it is more like an imaginary or hypothetical example (e.g. This could happen). It can be used to explain the kingdom of Heaven by telling a story which the listeners can understand. Because the lesson comes in the form of a story, the listener or reader can feel themselves being a part of it; it is more likely to make an impact on their lives.

Translation Suggestions

Parables or teaching stories are best translated as closely as possible to the way they were originally told. Because the parables are set in the culture of Bible times, there may be things that are not easily understood by a modern audience. Follow the guidelines for translating unknown practices or things. But because these are parables and not real events, some things that are known to the target audience can be substituted for things that are unknown to them, as long as they existed in the time period. Parables are best translated as a situation that can be understood within your own culture. The parable is a teaching story, so it is important that all of the details and parts of the story support the main point of the story. It is important that you understand this main point of the parable before you translate it.

When Jesus told a parable, he did not always intend for his hearers to understand what it meant right away (for example, the parable of the farmer planting seeds). So do not try to explain the story or what Jesus was teaching, but simply translate the parable. Use the form that your language has for communicating that a narrative is an imaginative story (or even a story whose purpose is to teach something) and not an account of a historical event.

Parables seldom (if ever) contain the names of specific individuals (That may be a key for you in identifying what is a parable and what is a narrative account.)

(See: Simile, Metaphor, Hypothetical Situations)

Examples from the Bible

Jesus said to them, “Certainly you will say this proverb to me, 'Doctor, heal yourself. Whatever we heard that you did in Capernaum, do it here in your hometown too.'” -Luke 4:23 ULB
Then he also told them a parable. “Can a blind person guide another blind person? If he did, they would both fall into a pit, would they not? -Luke 6:39 ULB

frames.text:
Create Faithful Translations

This page answers the question: What are faithful translations?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • The Qualities of a Good Translation
  • Translation Guidelines

Faithful Translations

To create a FAITHFUL translation of the Bible means that the translator identifies the translationWords and the unknown ideas in the text that are ambiguous or difficult to understand, and translates these parts consistently and faithfully.

  • Identify the translationWords of the original text. Translate these words or phrases consistently and faithfully for the both the Bible stories and Bible.
  • Look for unknown ideas in the places that are ambiguous or difficult to understand. Then, use the unfoldingWord biblical resources to see the helps that others suggest for translation.

translationWords

To translate translationWords, follow these four steps:

  1. Study the meaning of the original word.
  2. Compare the word with other words of similar meaning.
  3. Think of possible ways to translate the term. Choose one to try.
  4. Test the term you have chosen to see if others understand the meaning.

The goal of accurate translations is to translate the meaning of the original message clearly, accurately and naturally, keeping the author’s main focus in mind.

Remember: translationWords should be translated consistently.

Unknown Ideas

Sometimes a thing or custom is unknown in the target language. Possible solutions are to use a descriptive phrase, substitute something similar, use a foreign word from another language, use a more general word or use more specific words. See the lesson on Translate Unknowns for more information.

One kind of ‘unknown idea’ are words that refer to Jewish and Christian religious customs and beliefs. Some common unknown ideas are:

Names of places such as:

  • Temple (a building where the Israelites offered sacrifices to God)
  • Synagogue (a building where Jewish people assemble to worship God)
  • Sacrificial alter (a raised structure on which sacrifices were burned as gifts, or offerings, to God.)

Titles of people who hold an office such as:

  • Priest (someone who is chosen to relate to God on behalf of his people)
  • Pharisee (important group of Israel’s religious leaders in Jesus’ time)
  • Prophet (person who speaks God’s messages to people)
  • Son of Man
  • Son of God
  • King (ruler of an independent city, state or country).

Key Biblical Concepts such as:

  • Forgiveness (to not resent that person and not be angry at him for doing something hurtful)
  • Salvation (being saved or rescued from evil, enemies, or from danger)
  • Redemption (the act of buying back something that was previously owned or that was held captive)
  • Mercy (helping people who are in need)
  • Grace (help or regard that is given to someone who has not earned it).

Use terms that are faithful to the vocabulary of the original biblical languages. Terms addressing the relationship between God the Father and God the Son should be retained in translated content and clarified, if needed.

Watch the video for computer (see http://youtu.be/blnjk5p5y7s ) or mobile device (see http://youtu.be/W9n80tTXVX0 ).

frames.text:
Create AuthoritativeTranslations

This page answers the question: What are authoritative translations?

In order to understand this topic, it would be good to read:

  • The Qualities of a Good Translation
  • Translation Guidelines

Watch the video for computer (see http://youtu.be/CMDqYTaUsXU ) or mobile device (see http://youtu.be/a-A7dB-OYBs ). Being AUTHORITATIVE when translating the Bible is: Using reliable sources, determine the order of events, either logically or according to time. If they differ from the order in which they were presented in the original, rearrange them in your language to best communicate the meaning intended in the original language.

For a clear understanding of the text, refer to your Biblical resources such as the Translation Notes, Important Words and the Unfolding Word Dynamic Bible that explain the meaning of the source languages.

There are guidelines to follow:

  • Reorder events only if necessary.
  • Pay attention to the message of the source text
  • Do not paraphrase, and
  • Translate the meaning of the source text

Reorder events only if necessary:

Read different versions to see if clauses and phrases have been rearranged to show the actual order of events. You should translate them in the order in which they occur. Be sure not to change the meaning of the scripture. Also see the lesson on Order of Events.

Consider Revelation 5:2:

Who is worthy to open the scroll and break its seals? (ULB)

Compare:

“The person who is worthy to break the seals of the scroll and then to open it should come to do it!” (UDB) Which version is clearer? Your language also has its own structure for clear understanding. You may need to rearrange phrases to put thoughts into a logical order for your language. Remember to keep the meaning of the original author. In some versions you will see that sometimes two verses run together, and the content is re-arranged within them. This is okay as long as there is no change in meaning, and the re-ordering offers a clearer and more accurate translation. The UDB sometimes does this. For example, in Mark chapter 6, verses 8 and 9 are combined and rearranged in the translation. He also instructed them to wear sandals and to take along a walking stick when they were traveling. He told them not to take food, nor a bag in which to put supplies, nor any money for their journey. He also did not allow them to take extra clothing. Compare this with the ULB and notice the differences. >and he instructed them to take nothing for their journey but a staff. They should take no bread, no beggar's bag, and no money in their belts, but to wear sandals, and not to wear two tunics. Only combine or re-order verses occasionally, when necessary to avoid wrong meaning or confusion; Normally more than two verses should not be combined. Be careful when reordering longer passages. Pay attention to the message of the source text. Try to not concentrate on just the words of the message. Think about why God wanted each scripture included and what God is trying to tell or teach from the message. Do not paraphrase. Sometimes a translator changes the text so much that important information is left out. This is a paraphrase. It is important to keep all important ideas and words found in the source text in the target language text. The final guideline is to convey thoughts and intent behind the ULB source text as close as possible. Only make changes from the literal where needed so that the translation is clear to understand. Keep the original authority of God’s word whenever possible. Remember these are guidelines to follow: * Reorder events only if necessary. * Pay attention to the message of the source text * Do not paraphrase, and * Translate the meaning of the source text Remember, use the source literal biblical texts as the highest authority on translation of biblical content.
